post_text: School is officially in session! After two "first days" due to the staggered start, all students will attend school on Friday. Despite the challenges, our students showed up ready to learn and generally reported that they were excited to be back in the building. All safety precautions were carefully followed, and students and teachers alike are happy to back. Our awesome custodians clean desks daily and rotate the buildings throughout the day cleaning any touched surfaces including door handles and walls. A CSES sixth grader reported, "The masks aren't pleasant but we know we're protected." Two others added, "We're glad we're back in school so we're learning again. Even if the masks are hot, they keep us safe." Most agreed that "Today has been a lot better than we expected. Everything has been handled really well!"

Coronavirus has everything up in the air and our admin and board have been great at adapting to new regulations and information quickly.

post_text: Aquaponics is coming to Cambridge Springs Elementary School! Aquaponics is a system where there is a symbiotic relationship between raising aquatic animals and growing plants. They participated in an inquiry-based lesson to learn and observe how aquaponics works. Then, CSES was able to purchase a beginner system thanks to a Clearly Brighter Teacher Grant from the Northwestern REC. The new system will be set up in a central location in the school where the entire student body will be able to observe. Fourth grade students will be in charge of the aquaponics system. We look forward to what this hands-on experience will teach our students!

Education committee meeting Monday Nov 11th at 5:30 at Central Office. Here is the schedule for upcoming athletic meetings.

I think people are just starting to figure out that when this board holds meetings to gather input from the public, the intent is to actually get input from the public.

One great takeaway from tonight's meeting beyond the great suggestions about needing more yelling and bomb '01 Deville's was when Board President Mark Gerow said the answer doesnt always have to be either/or, sometimes the answer is AND.

The intent of this board is not to take opportunities away from kids or to save money combining or co-oping. It's to provide better opportunities to fit our district.

The process of looking at our sports and band started last May. It will be wrapping up in February with the board receiving recommendations afterwards. This is an inclusive process designed for residents to tell the board what the district wants instead of the district just telling residents what the board is going to do.

Get involved. We can only do better if we hear from all of you.
